questions.text: The following capnographic waveform is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The given capnographic waveform is suggestive of bronchospasm.

Capnography refers to the method of CO2 measurement as a function of time or volume. Bronchospasms may be due to respiratory pathologies like asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), or acute lung injury. Another cause of this waveform is a partially obstructed endotracheal tube or breathing circuit. Capnographic changes in bronchospasm include:

  • Loss of verticality of Phase II
  • The opening of the angle between phases 2 and 3 (α angle)
  • Increased upslope of phase III
  • No plateau before the next inspiration
  • Shark fin appearance - in severe cases

 Normal capnography is shown in the image below:

Other options:

Option A: Malignant hyperthermia would show a progressive rise in the end-tidal CO2 due to the increased metabolic rate.

Option C: Rebreathing will show the failure of CO2 to return to the baseline at the end of the expiration. The inspiratory CO2 remains above 0.

Option D: Accidental extubation or circuit disconnection would show a sudden cessation of CO2.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: An adolescent girl presents to you with lesions on her face. She confides in you that she frequently picks the real or imagined acne from her face and does this when she is under stress. The term used for this self-inflicted skin condition is called:
questions.solution:
Acne excoriée is a self-inflicted skin condition, in which the sufferer compulsively picks real or imagined acne lesions predominantly on the face. It is predominantly seen in adolescent girls. 

Other psychiatric disorders associated with acne are:

  • Body dysmorphic disorder: A small number of patients with BDD have acne as their prime symptom. The perceived acne is out of proportion to physical signs.
  • Eating disorders: Acne has been reported in anorexia nervosa. Acne itself may be a predisposing factor for anorexia in vulnerable teenage age groups who adopt a diet in an attempt to control their acne. 

Other options:

Option B: Acne mechanica: This term describes acneform lesions that occur at the site of repeated mechanical trauma and/or frictional obstruction of the pilosebaceous outlet. Examples include mechanical pressure from high‐necked jerseys, shoulder pads, seat backs in trucks, or adhesive plasters causing acneform folliculitis.

Option C: Acne conglobata: Acne conglobata represents a rare and severe form of acne characterized by multiple and extensive inflammatory papules, tender nodules, and abscesses which commonly coalesce to form malodorous draining sinus tracts.

Option D: Acne fulminans: Acne fulminans or acne maligna is a rare and severe destructive form of acne presenting primarily in adolescent males. It most frequently affects the trunk but can affect the face. It presents acutely in association with systemic symptoms.

questions.text: A farmer presented with a mass on his jaw, containing draining sinuses with purulent discharge. The culture of the discharge from the sinus grew colonies, which are shown in the image given below. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing molar tooth colonies that are characteristic of actinomyces species. The given clinical scenario describes a lumpy jaw seen in cervicofacial actinomycosis.

Actinomycosis is a chronic suppurative and granulomatous infection caused by Actinomyces. It presents as one of the following clinical types:

  • Cervicofacial actinomycosis- fluctuant mass in the jaw area producing draining fistulas (lumpy jaw)
  • Thoracic actinomycosis- pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. 
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- following ruptured appendix or ulcer. It may involve multiple organs.

The image given below shows cervicofacial actinomycosis.

The image given below shows a patient with multiple cutaneous lesions caused by actinomycosis.

Actinomycosis can spread to bones and surrounding tissue and produce multiple discharging sinuses.

Diagnosis is by examination of the pus from sinuses, sputum, or tissue specimens for sulfur granules. These granules are yellow, hard, lobulated, and made of tissue and bacterial filaments. Gram staining shows filamentous gram-positive bacteria.

Specimens should be cultured anaerobically on appropriate media such as chocolate blood agar, brain heart infusion broth, and brucella blood agar with hemin and vitamin K1. They may form molar-tooth colonies on agar and grows as clumps within the broth. Actinomyces species are mostly facultative anaerobes. 

Treatment is with IV penicillin for 2-6 weeks followed by oral therapy with penicillin or amoxicillin for serious infections.

Other options:

Option A: Cryptococcus usually manifests as meningitis with headache, neck stiffness, and disorientation. In addition, there may be lesions in the skin, lungs, or other organs. Cryptococcus produces whitish mucoid colonies. On microscopy, spherical budding yeast cells with a thick capsule are seen.

Option B: Bacillus anthracis usually manifests as cutaneous anthrax. The typical lesion has a characteristic central black eschar with marked edema. Microscopy shows gram-positive rods and culture on blood agar produce nonhemolytic gray to white, tenacious colonies with a ground-glass appearance. Comma-shaped outgrowths may project from the colony.

Option D: Klebsiella is a gram-negative, encapsulated, non-motile bacterium. It can cause pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and skin and wound infections. It produces a very viscous, mucoid growth when cultured on ordinary media. On MacConkey agar, they grow as lactose-forming colonies.

questions.text: Parkinson’s triangle is related to:
questions.solution:
The space between the trochlear and ophthalmic nerves at the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus is known as the infratrochlear or Parkinson’s triangle.

Parkinson’s triangle (infratrochlear triangle) is a triangle formed by the following structures:
  • Medial border: Inferior margin of the trochlear nerve from its beginning in the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus to its transit through the superior orbital fissure
  • Lateral border: Superior margin of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve 
  • Base: Line connecting the entry points of these 2 nerves into the cavernous sinus

It gives access to the horizontal cavernous part, posterior genu and meningohypophyseal trunk of the internal carotid artery, and abducens nerve.

questions.text:
Match the following DNA polymerase enzymes with their functions :
DNA Polymerase Function
1. β A. Primase
2. γ B. DNA repair
3. α C. Processive, lagging strand synthesis
4. δ D. Mitochondrial DNA synthesis
questions.solution:
The option which is correctly matched is B with 1-B, 2-D, 3-A, 4-C

DNA Polymerase Function
1. β B. DNA repair
2. γ D. Mitochondrial DNA synthesis
3. α A. Primase
4. δ C. Processive, lagging strand synthesis

 

DNA polymerase engages in DNA replication and has 3 essential properties :

  • Chain elongation: It accounts for the rate at which DNA polymerization occurs. The rate is in nucleotides per second (nt/s)
  • Processivity: This is an expression of the number of nucleotides added to the nascent chain before the polymerase disengages from the template
  • Proofreading: The function where copying errors are identified and corrected

The prokaryotic DNA polymerases are DNA polymerases I, II, and III.

  • DNA polymerase I: Gap filling following DNA replication, repair, and recombination
  • DNA polymerase II: DNA proofreading and repair.
  • DNA polymerase III: The primary enzyme for the synthesis of the leading strand of DNA. 

Eukaryotic cells have a large number of DNA polymerases primarily involved in DNA repair

  • DNA Pol α synthesizes RNA primers which are responsible for the initiation of DNA synthesis.
  • DNA pol β has a primary role in DNA repair
  • DNA pol γ is responsible for mitochondrial DNA synthesis
  • DNA pol ε and pol δ catalyze leading and lagging strand synthesis. 

The following image is a schematic image showing DNA replication in a eukaryotic cell :

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criteria for discharging a patient recovering from dengue?
questions.solution:
The absence of fever for 12 hours is not a criterion for the discharge of a patient recovering from dengue. Fever should be absent for at least 24 hours without the use of antipyretic drugs in order to discharge a patient recovering from dengue.

Criteria for discharge of patients recovering from dengue:

  • Absence of fever for at least 24 hours without the use of antipyretic drugs
  • Platelet count >50,000/mm3
  • Return of appetite
  • Adequate urine output
  • Visible clinical improvement
  • Minimum of 2-3 days after recovery from shock
  • No respiratory distress from pleural effusion or ascites

questions.text: A young woman presented to the emergency with epistaxis due to multiple episodes of continuous violent sneezes. To control the bleeding the following technique was performed as shown in the image given below. This method helps her to control bleeding from the septal branches of all of the following arteries, except _______.
questions.solution:
The image shows Trotter’s method. This method helps her to control bleeding from all of the given arteries, except the septal branch of the posterior ethmoidal artery. 

Trotter's method is a step to control epistaxis from Little’s area. Here, the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth and pinching the nose with the thumb and index finger for about 5 minutes. The septal branch of the posterior ethmoidal artery does not take part in the vascular anastomoses seen in this area. Hence, it fails to prevent bleeding from this artery.

Little’s area is situated at the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum, just above the vestibule. It is the most common site of epistaxis in children and young adults. Septal branches of four arteries anastomose here to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach’s plexus. The arteries include:

  • Septal branch of the superior labial artery
  • Septal branch of the anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Septal branch of the sphenopalatine artery
  • Septal branch of the greater palatine artery

Note: Woodruff's plexus is a site of posterior epistaxis in adults. It is a plexus of veins situated inferior to the posterior end of inferior turbinate.

questions.text: Nysten’s rule describes the sequential onset of:
questions.solution:
Nysten’s rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis.

Rigor mortis is also known as cadaveric rigidity or death stiffening. It refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death. Both voluntary and involuntary muscles are involved. In India, it begins 1-2 hours following death.

Nysten's rule describes the order of appearance of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups. It first appears in the myocardium, which becomes rigid in an hour. The order of appearance of rigor mortis is:

Myocardium> eyelids > neck and lower jaw > face> muscles of chest > upper limb> abdomen > lower limb > fingers and toes (proximo-distal progression)

It passes off in the same order of its appearance.

Medicolegal importance:

  • Sign of death
  • Helps in estimating the time of death, but is not reliable
  • Indicates the position of the body at the time of death

Conditions that simulate rigor mortis include heat stiffening, cold stiffening, and cadaveric spasm.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with growth over the nasal aspect of the left eye. Initially, it was small but has now progressed to the size shown in the image below. The vision was 6/12 in the left eye and refraction examination revealed astigmatism. Choose the correct statement regarding the management of this case.

choices.text: It is best left alone for spontaneous resolution
Only medical management is sufficient at this stage
Limbal conjunctival tissue from the same eye can be used for grafting
Application of mitomycin C drops reduces recurrence with no complications

questions.solution:
The clinical case and image point to a diagnosis of pterygium with astigmatism, for which conjunctival autografting is an effective method of treatment after excision. Conjunctival tissue can be taken from the limbus on the same side or from the other eye for grafting.

A pterygium is a degenerative subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea. It is most commonly seen on the nasal aspect of the eye. It is made up of three parts:

  • cap (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge)
  • head
  • body

Patients may be asymptomatic or present with irritation, grittiness, or episodes of inflammation. As they enlarge, it may obstruct vision and lead to astigmatism.

Treatment: 

  • A pterygium is best left alone unless:
    • It is progressing towards the pupillary area
    • Causes excessive astigmatism
    • Restricts ocular motility
    • Causes disfigurement.
  • Excision: Simple excision of the pterygium is associated with a high recurrence rate, and should be combined with:
    • Mitomycin C drops- applied pre-operatively/ intra-operatively or post-operatively to prevent a recurrence. However, it may lead to complications like scleral necrosis, cataract, and iritis and should be used judiciously. 
    • Beta irradiation
    • Conjunctival autografting- limbal tissue from the same or other eye is grafted and secured with fibrin glue or sutures.
    • Amniotic membrane graft
    • Peripheral lamellar keratoplasty if the lesion is deep.

questions.text:
A 2-week-old infant with ambiguous genitalia (as shown in the picture) presents with an episode of dehydration and shock, requiring hospitalization. Levels of which of the following would be increased in the infant?
  1. Cortisol
  2. Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)
  3. 17-hydroxyprogesterone
  4. Serum androgens
  5. Plasma renin
questions.solution:
Ambiguous genitalia (virilization) with dehydration and shock (salt-wasting crisis) suggests the diagnosis of congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Lab investigations would reveal cortisol to be decreased while 17-hydroxyprogesterone, ACTH, serum androgens, and plasma renin would be increased.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is a set of autosomal recessive disorders characterized by impaired synthesis of cortisol. This cortisol deficiency increases the secretion of ACTH, which leads to adrenocortical hyperplasia.

21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common cause of CAH. The synthesis of both cortisol and aldosterone requires 21-hydroxylation, hence both hormones are deficient. These babies present at 10–14 days of age with progressive weight loss, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, dehydration, hypoglycemia, and hypotension. Without treatment, shock, cardiac arrhythmias, and death may occur within days or weeks.

questions.text:
During a biochemical screening, an obstetrician identifies that a woman is carrying a fetus with trisomy 18. Which of the following markers would likely be low in this screening test?

1. Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein
2. Beta human chorionic gonadotropin
3. Unconjugated estriol
4. Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 2, 3, and 4. All of the above-given findings are decreased in trisomy 18 (Edward's syndrome). Maternal serum AFP, beta hCG, unconjugated estriol, and pregnancy-associated plasma protein A levels are reduced.

Combined first-trimester screening tests: It is performed between 11 and 14 weeks gestation. It comprises of:

  • Human chorionic gonad­otropin (hCG)
  • Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
  • Sonographic measurement of the nuchal translucency (NT)

The abnormalities seen on the triple screen are tabulated below:

 Parameter Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal

Quadruple testing is done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation. It comprises:

  • Maternal serum AFP
  • Human chorionic gonadotropin
  • Unconjugated estriol
  • Inhibin A

Trisomy 18 or Edwards’ syndrome is a condition characterised by intellectual disability, micrognathia, low-set ears, rocker-bottom feet, and congenital heart diseases. The most characteristic finding is a clenched fist with overlapping fingers i.e. the index finger overlies the third and fourth fingers, while the fifth finger overlaps the fourth. This syndrome is also associated with polyhydramnios and a single umbilical artery.

questions.text:
A young boy who is anticipating his board exams has been increasingly isolated with flat affect for the past 6 months. He has disorganized speech and says he hears a voice telling him that the government is tracking him. On mental status examination, you find that he is depressed. Considering the likely diagnosis, which of the following can be considered a good prognostic factor for him?
  1. Presence of depression
  2. Male sex
  3. Presence of a stressor
  4. Young age of onset
  5. Presence of negative symptoms
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario showing a flat affect, auditory hallucinations, and disorganized speech is highly suggestive of schizophrenia. The presence of a stressor and depression are good prognostic factors.

Schizophrenia is a psychosis, a type of mental illness characterized by distortions in thinking, perception, emotions, language, sense of self, and behavior.

The DSM-5 criteria to diagnose schizophrenia require a total duration of 6 months. Within this 6-month period, there must be at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms (overt psychotic symptoms) where 2 or more of the following have to be present, with at least one among the symptoms a, b, or c: 

  1. Delusion
  2. Hallucination
  3. Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)
  4. Disorganized behavior
  5. Affective flattening or other negative symptoms

Studies have pointed out that more than half of the patients generally have a poor prognosis. Poor prognostic factors are associated with repeated hospitalizations, exacerbation of symptoms, and suicide attempts. At least one-third of people with schizophrenia experiences complete remission of symptoms. Some people with schizophrenia experience worsening and remission of symptoms periodically throughout their lives, others a gradual worsening of symptoms over time.

The good and the poor prognostic factors are given below:

Good Prognostic factors   Poor prognostic factors
Acute onset Insidious onset
Late-onset Early-onset
Presence of a stressor Absence of a stressor
Presence of depression No depression
Positive symptoms Negative symptoms
Family history of mood disorder Family history of schizophrenia
Married, female sex Single, male sex

 

Based on the predominant clinical presentation, schizophrenia is divided into five subtypes: paranoid, disorganized, undifferentiated, catatonic, and residual. Antipsychotics form the mainstay of treatment, while psychotherapy is used as an adjunct.

questions.text:
Given below are colours representing the various available intravenous cannulae. Arrange the following in the decreasing order of sizes.

1 - Pink 
2 - Grey
3 - Green
4 - Orange
5 - Blue
questions.solution:
The decreasing order of size for the given cannulae are - orange, grey, green, pink, and blue.

Standard wire gauge (SWG) is used to size cannulas. It is a measure of the cross-sectional area. It refers to the number of wires of the same size as the cannula that could pass through a hole of a standard size in parallel. Therefore larger cannulae have a smaller gauge number.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct regarding Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome?

1. Arborizing pattern of connective tissue
2. Mutation in the STK11 gene
3. Multiple hamartomatous polyps
4. Autosomal recessive
5. Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
questions.solution:
The correct statements regarding Peutz-Jeghers syndrome are 1, 2, and 3.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant, hereditary disorder characterized by multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation. The pigmentation is particularly evident on the face, buccal mucosa, hands, feet, and perianal and genital regions. This rare syndrome presents at a median age of 11 years.

Germline heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the gene STK11 are present in half the individuals with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Histologic examination shows a characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by the normal-appearing intestinal epithelium.

A complication of Peutz-Jeghers polyps is intussusception, which is occasionally fatal. Peutz-Jegher syndrome is associated with a markedly increased risk of colon, pancreatic, breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers.

Note:- Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium is seen in FAP, not Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male patient presented with painful swelling below the knee joint. On examination, there is localized tenderness over the tibial tuberosity. The X-ray image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray image shows a traction injury of the tibial tuberosity, at the site where the patellar tendon is inserted, which is characteristic of Osgood-Schlatter Disease, also known as apophysitis of the tibial tuberosity.

The condition is usually seen in young adolescents and may not be associated with any injury.

The presenting feature is a painful lump below the knee joint. On examination, the lump is tender and its situation over the tibial tuberosity is diagnostic of the disease.

Other options:

Option a: Jumper’s knee, also known as patellar tendinitis is an inflammation of the proximal patellar tendon, which occurs due to overuse injury and is usually seen in athletes.

Option c: Sinding-Larsen-Johansson Syndrome is seen where there is a partial rupture or avulsion of the distal patellar tendon, where it inserts into the patella, leading to traction tendonitis and calcification in the patellar ligament.

Option d: Osteochondritis Dissecans is a condition characterized by demarcation or separation and necrosis of a part of articular cartilage and bone. The condition is often associated with intra-articular loose bodies.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency room with complaints of nausea, muscle weakness, and a sense of extreme fatigue. He is a known case of CKD on treatment with enalapril. His ECG is given below. What is the first step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows peaked T waves, flattened P waves, and broad QRS complexes, suggesting hyperkalemia. This patient also has chronic kidney disease and is on treatment with an ACE inhibitor, enalapril. Both of these factors are independent risk factors for hyperkalemia. The first step in the management of hyperkalemia is the administration of IV calcium gluconate.

ECG changes seen in hyperkalemia vary with the level of serum K+ (normal serum K+ is 3.5-5.5 mEq/L):

  • 5.5-6.5 mEq/L- tall, peaked T waves
  • 6.5-7.5 mEq/L- flattening of P waves
  • 7.0-8.0 mEq/L - widening of QRS complexes
  • >8.0 mEq/L - sine wave pattern of ECG

The resting membrane potential of excitable cells is close to the resting membrane potential for K+. In the resting state, there is a constant leakage of K+ out of the cell. If the K+ is higher in the extracellular environment (hyperkalemia), less K+ will leak out of the cell because the gradient is unfavorable. This increases the positive charge inside the cell, leading to the membrane potential being pushed more toward the threshold. In other words, the cell is now more excitable. 

Calcium administration counteracts this by reducing the excitability of the cells and maintaining the membrane potential at the actual resting value. Calcium is administered by intravenous infusion over 2-3 minutes with cardiac monitoring. The effect of the infusion lasts for up to 60 minutes. During this time, the steps to correct K+ levels can be taken. These steps include:

  • 10 units of IV insulin followed immediately by 50 mL 50% dextrose bolus
  • Inhaled β2 agonists such as albuterol
  • Cation exchange resins such as sodium polystyrene sulfonate and patiromer can be used for the management of both acute and chronic hyperkalemia
  • Hemodialysis is the most effective method to reduce K+ concentration

Note that intravenous bicarbonate administration does not have a role in the management of acute hyperkalemia.

questions.text: Your physiology laboratory partner is being examined during a cardiac system practical. Her heart rate is 80 beats/min and her BP is 100/70 mmHg measured in the supine position. Her heart rate increases to 90 beats/min on standing. Which of the following must have prompted the increase in heart rate?
questions.solution:
The decrease in venous return is the likely initial event to have prompted an increase in heart rate.

When a person stands up from a lying down position, it causes pooling of the blood in the legs, due to gravity. This reduces the venous return and causes a decrease in cardiac output. Reduced cardiac output leads to a fall in blood pressure, which in turn causes reduced firing from baroreceptors. As a result, the vagal tone is suppressed, leading to increased heart rate.

 Baroreceptors are mechanoreceptors receptors located in the heart and adventitia of the blood vessels.

  • Types based on location
    • Carotid sinus and aortic arch receptors (high-pressure regions)
    • Cardiopulmonary receptors (low-pressure regions)
  • Afferents
    • Carotid sinus- a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX CN)– the carotid sinus nerve (sinus nerve of Hering)
    • Aortic arch receptor- a branch of the vagus nerve (X CN)– aortic depressor nerve
  • Center for Reflex
    • Medulla (nucleus tractus solitarius)
  • Efferents
    • Sympathetic and parasympathetic neurons to heart and vasculature

Related Pearl: Factors Affecting Heart Rate

Heart rate is accelerated by
  • Decreased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Increased activity of atrial stretch receptors
  • Inspiration
  • Excitement
  • Anger
  • Pain
  • Hypoxia
  • Exercise
  • Thyroid hormones
  • Fever

The Heart is slowed by
  • Increased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Expiration
  • Grief
  • Stimulation of pain fibers in trigeminal nerve
  • Increased intracranial pressure

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are true in the given graph?

1 – Drug A has more potency and efficacy when compared to drug B
2 – Drug C has the same efficacy as Drug A
3 – Drug B and D have the same potency
4 – Drug D has more efficacy but less potency than drug C
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 4 are true about the given dose-response curve. Drug C has the same efficacy as drug A. Drug D has more efficacy but has less potency than Drug C.

Potency is the dose or concentration of a drug required to produce 50% of the drug’s maximal effect. The more the curve is on the left in a dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency. 

Efficacy is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug and is determined by the peak of the curve. It reflects the capacity of the drug to bind a receptor and produce a cellular response.

In the above graph order of potency is A>B>C>D. Drugs A and C have same efficacy, and drug B and D have the same efficacy.

The slope of the DRC also has significance. A steep slope implies that a moderate increase in dose markedly increases the response. Thus, for such drugs, the dose needs individualization. A flat slope implies that over a wide dose range, only a little increase in response will occur. Thus, these drugs can be given in standard doses.

questions.text: Which of the following effects indicate the stochastic effect of radiation seen in a person working in a diagnostic center and having an increased risk of radiation exposure?
questions.solution:
Heritable mutations are stochastic effects that occur as a result of radiation exposure.

The harmful effects of radiation may be classified into two general categories:

  • Stochastic effects
  • Nonstochastic or deterministic effects

Stochastic effects (chance or random effects): These effects of ionizing radiation are chance events. The probability of the effect increases with the dose. But the severity of the effect is independent of the dose received. There is no threshold. These effects are associated with damage to the DNA of cells.

Examples of stochastic effects include secondary malignancies and heritable mutations.

Non-stochastic/Deterministic effects (non-random effects): These effects are related directly to the absorbed radiation dose. The severity of the effect increases as the dose increases. A deterministic effect typically has a threshold below which the effect does not occur.

Examples of nonstochastic or deterministic effects include radiation-induced skin erythema, lens opacification, and transient decrease in sperm count.

questions.text: Caroli's disease is __________
questions.solution:
Caroli's disease is a type V choledochal cyst.

Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic biliary tree. They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain.

Choledochal cyst is classified into five types:

  • Type I: is a simple cyst that can involve any portion of the CBD.
  • Type II: It is described as an isolated diverticulum arising from the wall of the CBD
  • Type III: They arise from the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct and are also known as choledochocele.
  • Type IVA: The cysts consist of multiple dilatations of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type IVB: These choledochal cysts are multiple dilatations involving only the extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type V (Caroli’s disease): It consists of multiple dilatations limited to the intrahepatic bile ducts.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.
